content: I've added "space-separated" in Input section based on the forum comment ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-how-many-roads-lead-to-rome/195256/2 ).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved it in few minutes, simple to understand, a good introduction to graph traversal.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The description is clear and it is a good exercise for people not used to algorithms like BFS but I wonder (no gatekeeping from me I swear) if this is really "Medium" level as there are no real constraint like differents paths using the same city, etc. Seems more like "Easy" to me but this is only my view :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good introduction to BFS
Path finding without the hurdle of doing it in a 2D grid, I like it! Fun puzzle to introduce the concept.

Hi there. Loved the theme and the task. Very nice.
Was fun to solve too.  =)

I'd suggest you reformat the description a bit,
it could be a bit more readable in my opinion. 
What about something like this?

```
Someone just told you all roads lead to Rome.
As a matter of fact, this is not true.

In order to restore scientific truth, you must write 
a program that counts the actual number of paths from Paris to Rome
where any city is at most visited once per. path.

To start with, you're given a collection of all 
paths that directly connect individual cities
and where each city is defined by a number from 1 to 100.

Paris has label 1, and Rome has label 100.

...
```

Funny and easy puzzle when using the Breadth First Search algorithm, with a little modification :-).

One suggestion is you may had a short example with the case of paths using both ways, like:
3
1 90
20 90
20 100

Thank you!
I added an example similar to yours.

Hi ! Thanks for this useful comment.
You are right, this was definitely not a good idea to call 'roads' what we use to call 'paths' in graphs theory. (I wanted to stick to the idiom 'every road lead to Rome')

I understand and I was wondering too if it was better as a "medium" or "easy" puzzle. 
I chose "medium" because to me, working with graphs isn't a part of the mose basic stuff you can do when programming (which would be conditions, calculus, distances, text manipulations, ...).
Also, it has to do with recursion, which I consider as the "elevator" from a beginner level to a medium one.
And finally, I saw in the comments that many people think about BFS to solve it, which works. I'm not an expert myself but I think this might be more elegant to design a more specific answer to the problem, which is only about counting (and do nothing else with) a collection of paths where we know for sure they may never be infinite.

I would be interested in collecting other people's opinions about this question: easy or medium difficulty?
I think medium is fine. There is already a pathfinding puzzle in easy (Treasure map) and it's not well liked. People thinks it is miscategorized (that's my opinion too).
